data.title: Nationalities & countries in German: Pronounce places perfectly
data.meta_description: Soon youâll be able to make friends from all over the world and learn all about their countries, nationalities, and hometowns in German!
data.text:
There are hundreds of countries and thousands of cities in the world, and every single one of us has a different idea of home. Being able to learn about each otherâs backgrounds is one of the greatest benefits of language learning.

One of the first questions to ask when you meet a German-speaker is âââWhere are you from?â and if you found our helpful guide on how to ask people about their origins in German, you already know this one.

The question itself is easy enough but the answer can be a lot more complex.

Not all German-speakers are actually from a German-speaking country. Thatâs why we collected a long list of countries and cities in German that will help you understand peopleâs origins better. Soon youâll be able to make friends from all over the world and learn all about their countries and hometowns!

List of continents in German

To give people a rough idea where youâre from, you can always start with the continent or larger area, before you go into more detail about your country or city.

English German IPA Continent Kontinent [ËkÉntinÉnt] Africa Afrika [ËaËfÊika] North America Nordamerika [ËnÉÊtÊaËmeËÊika] Central America Mittelamerika [ËmÉªtlÌ©ÊaËmeËÊika] South America SÃ¼damerika [zyËtÊaËmeËÊika] Asia Asien [ËaËziÌ¯Én] Europe Europa [ÉÉªÌ¯ËÊoËpa] Oceania Ozeanien [otÍ¡seËaËniÌ¯Én] Australia Australien [aÊÌ¯sËtÊaËliÌ¯Én]

List of countries in German

âCountriesâ in German is âLÃ¤nderâ and the singular is âdas Landâ. This is related to the English âlandâ and the original meaning focuses more on the geography of the land itself than on its political borders. Weâve listed the majority of countries for you, divided by continent. Luckily, theyâre all very similar to the English names, so memorizing them shouldnât be too hard!

African countries in German

The population census shows that 1% of Germanyâs population consists of minorities with passports from African countries, mostly from Morocco, Eritrea and Nigeria. Many more officially have German citizenship but a background that involves at least one of these African countries:

American countries in German

Here is a list of American countries in German - from Canada to Nicaragua and all the way down to Chile.

Asian countries in German

Youâll meet many people with Asian backgrounds in Germany. Turks are the largest minority group, making up for almost 4% of the German population. In fact, Berlin alone is home to more than 200,000 residents claiming Turkish heritage.

English German IPA Flag Armenia Armenien [aÊËmeËniÌ¯Én] ð¦ð² Azerbaijan Aserbaidschan [ËazÉÊbaÉªÌ¯ËdÍ¡ÊaËn] ð¦ð¿ Bangladesh Bangladesch [ËbaÅÉ¡laËdÉÊ] ð§ð© Cambodia Kambodscha [kamËbÉdÍ¡Êa] ð°ð­ China China [ËÃ§iËna] ð¨ð³ India Indien [ËÉªndiÌ¯Én] ð®ð³ Indonesia Indonesien [ÉªndoËneËziÌ¯Én] ð®ð© Iran Iran [iËÊaËn] ð®ð· Iraq Irak [iËÊaËk] ð®ð¶ Japan Japan [ËjaËpan] ð¯ðµ Jordan Jordanien [jÉÊËdaËniÌ¯Én] ð¯ð´ Kazakhstan Kasachstan [ËkaËzaxËstaËn] ð°ð¿ North Korea Nordkorea [ËnÉÊtkoËÊeËa] ð°ðµ South Korea SÃ¼dkorea [ËzyËtkoËÊeËa] ð°ð· Lebanon Der Libanon [ËliËbanÉn] ð±ð§ Malaysia Malaysia [maËlaÉªÌ¯ziÌ¯a] ð²ð¾ Mongolia Die Mongolei [ËmÉÅÉ¡oËlaÉªÌ¯] ð²ð³ Myanmar Myanmar [ËmiÌ¯anmaËÉÌ¯] ð²ð² Oman Der Oman [oËmaËn] ð´ð² Pakistan Pakistan [ËpaËkÉªstaËn] ðµð° Palestine PalÃ¤stina [palÉsËtiËna] ðµð¸ Philippines Die Philippinen [ËfilÉªËpiËnÉn] ðµð­ Qatar Katar [kaËtaËÉÌ¯] ð¶ð¦ Saudi Arabia Saudi-Arabien [ËzaÊÌ¯diÊaËÊaËbiÌ¯Én] ð¸ð¦ Singapore Singapur [ËzÉªÅÉ¡apuËÉÌ¯] ð¸ð¬ Sri Lanka Sri Lanka [sÊiË ËlaÅka] ð±ð° Thailand Thailand [ËtaÉªÌ¯lant] ð¹ð­ Turkey Die TÃ¼rkei [tÊÊËkaÉªÌ¯] ð¹ð· United Arab Emirates Vereinigte Arabische Emirate [fÉÉÌ¯ËÊaÉªÌ¯nÉªÃ§tÉ ÊaËÊaËbÉªÊÉ ËÊemiËÊaËtÉ] ð¦ðª Uzbekistan Usbekistan [ÊsËbeËkÉªstaËn] ðºð¿ Vietnam Vietnam [viÌ¯ÉtËnam] ð»ð³ Yemen Der Jemen [ËjeËmÉn] ð¾ðª

European countries in German

Did you know that the name for the European continent is derived from the Phoenician princess Europa, a fictional character in Greek mythology? Therefore, in German, Spanish, Italian and other languages the word for Europe is âEuropaâ.

English German IPA Flag Albania Albanien [alËbaËniÌ¯Én] ð¦ð± Andorra Andorra [anËdÉÊa] ð¦ð© Austria Ãsterreich [ËÃ¸ËstÉÊaÉªÌ¯Ã§] ð¦ð¹ Belgium Belgien [ËbÉlÉ¡iÌ¯Én] ð§ðª Bulgaria Bulgarien [bÊlËÉ¡aËÊiÉn] ð§ð¬ Croatia Kroatien [kÊoËaËtÍ¡siÌ¯Én] ð­ð· Cyprus Zypern [ËtÍ¡syËpÉn] ð¨ð¾ Czechia Tschechien [ËtÍ¡ÊÉÃ§iÌ¯Én] ð¨ð¿ Denmark DÃ¤nemark [ËdÉËnÉËmaÊk] ð©ð° Finland Finnland [ËfÉªnlant] ð«ð® France Frankreich [ËfÊaÅkÊaÉªÌ¯Ã§] ð«ð· Germany Deutschland [ËdÉÉªÌ¯tÍ¡Êlant] ð©ðª Greece Griechenland [ËÉ¡ÊiËÃ§nÌ©Ëlant] ð¬ð· Hungary Ungarn [ËÊÅÉ¡aÊn] ð­ðº Iceland Island [ËiËslant] ð®ð¸ Ireland Irland [ËÉªÊlant] ð®ðª Italy Italien [iËtaËliÌ¯Én] ð®ð¹ Lithuania Litauen [ËlÉªtaÊÌ¯Én] ð±ð¹ Luxembourg Luxemburg [ËlÊksmÌ©ËbÊÊk] ð±ðº The Netherlands Die Niederlande [ËniËdÉËlandÉ] ð³ð± Norway Norwegen [ËnÉÊËveËÉ¡nÌ©] ð³ð´ Poland Polen [ËpoËlÉn] ðµð± Portugal Portugal [ËpÉÊtuÉ¡al] ðµð¹ Romania RumÃ¤nien [ÊuËmÉËniÌ¯Én] ð·ð´ Russia Russland [ËÊÊslant] ð·ðº Serbia Serbien [ËzÉÊbiÌ¯Én] ð·ð¸ Slovakia Die Slowakei [ËslovaËkaÉªÌ¯] ð¸ð° Slovenia Slowenien [sloËveËniÌ¯Én] ð¸ð® Spain Spanien [ËÊpaËniÌ¯Én] ðªð¸ Sweden Schweden [ËÊveËdnÌ©] ð¸ðª Switzerland Die Schweiz [ÊvaÉªÌ¯tÍ¡s] ð¨ð­ Ukraine Die Ukraine [ËukÊaËiËnÉ] ðºð¦ United Kingdom Vereinigtes KÃ¶nigreich [fÉÉÌ¯ËÊaÉªÌ¯nÉªÃ§tÉs ËkÃ¸ËnÉªÃ§ËÊaÉªÌ¯Ã§] ð¬ð§

Oceanian countries in German

If you dug a hole to the other side of the world in Germany, youâd be floating in the ocean somewhere off the East coast of New Zealand. Nothingâs further away than Oceanian countries and islands but luckily for those of us trying to flee the cold German weather, soaking in the sun on Samoa is only a couple of flights away.

English German IPA Flag Australia Australien [aÊÌ¯sËtÊaËliÌ¯Én] ð¦ðº New Zealand Neuseeland [nÉÉªÌ¯ËzeËlant] ð³ð¿ Federated States of Micronesia FÃ¶derierte Staaten von Mikronesien [fÃ¸dÉËÊiËÉÌ¯tnÌ© ËÊtatnÌ© fÉn ËmikÊoËneËziÌ¯Én] ð«ð² Fiji Fidschi [ËfÉªdÍ¡Êi] ð«ð¯ Kiribati Kiribati [kiÊiËbaËti] ð°ð® Papua New Guinea Papua-Neuguinea [ËpaËpuanÉÉªÌ¯É¡iËneËa] ðµð¬ Samoa Samoa [zaËmoËa] ð¼ð¸ Solomon Islands Die Salomoninseln [ËzaËlomÉnËÊÉªnzlÌ©n] ð¸ð§ Tonga Tonga [ËtÉÅÉ¡a] ð¹ð´ Vanuatu Vanuatu [ËvanuËaËtuË] ð»ðº

List of major cities in German

Of course we canât list every city in the world and weâre so sorry about all the beautiful little smalltowns and hidden gems weâre missing - but for now, letâs get started with the major metropolises and biggest cities in German.

List of cities in the United States

Good news! All the American cities are either the same in German or theyâre extremely similar to the English name and if you pronounce them a little different than the German-speakers, you could argue that technically youâre still right and theyâre wrong. After all, you wouldnât tell a German-speaker how to pronounce German cities, right?

Nationalities in German

Actual nationalities are only important when it comes to legal matters and visa applications. Other than that, all that matters is which nationality you identify with and where you feel at home. Hereâs how you say a number of different nationalities in German. Youâll see that most of them follow the same pattern.

Nationality in English Nationality in German IPA Argentinian Argentinisch [aÊÉ¡ÉnËtiËnÉªÊ] Spanish Spanisch [ËÊpaËnÉªÊ] Mexican Mexikanisch [mÉksiËkaËnÉªÊ] Colombian Kolumbianisch [kolÊmËbiÌ¯aËnÉªÊ] Peruvian Peruanisch [peÊuËaËnÉªÊ] Puerto Rican Puerto-ricanisch [ËpuÌ¯ÉÊtoËÊiËkËaËnÉªÊ] Costa Rican Costa-ricanisch [ËkÉstaÊiËkaËnÉªÊ] US-American US-Amerikanisch [u: És ameÊiËkaËnÉªÊ] Canadian Kanadisch [kaËnaËdÉªÊ] British Britisch [ËbÊÉªtÉªÊ] French FranzÃ¶sisch [fÊanËtÍ¡sÃ¸ËzÉªÊ] German Deutsch [dÉÉªÌ¯tÍ¡Ê] Italian Italienisch [ËitaËliÌ¯eËnÉªÊ] Swiss Schweizerisch [ËÊvaÉªÌ¯tÍ¡sÉÊÉªÊ] Swedish Schwedisch [ËÊveËdÉªÊ] Australian Australisch [aÊÌ¯sËtÊaËlÉªÊ] Japanese Japanisch [jaËpaËnÉªÊ] Chinese Chinesisch [Ã§iËneËzÉªÊ] Indian Indisch [ËÉªndÉªÊ] South African SÃ¼dafrikanisch [ËzyËtÊafÊiËkaËnÉªÊ] Egyptian Ãgyptisch [ÉËÉ¡ÊptÉªÊ] Moroccan Marokkanisch [maÊÉËkaËnÉªÊ]

What do Germans like about other countries?

In the following video, the German Youtubers Cari and Janusz ask fellow Germans an interesting question: What do you like about other countries?

As most Germans love to travel, everyone has their own experiences with different countries and some personal insights in what ways they wish Germans were more like people from other countries.

What Germans like about other Countries | Easy German 195

Some love the Costa Rican ability for spontaneous salsa dancing. Others admire the Australian open-mindedness, British generosity or the Italian fashion sense.

You might have noticed in the video that the Germans seem very critical of their own culture but a few non-Germans asked on social media singled out German characteristics as something positive:

Take a slice of each country you visit

One of the questions asked in the video is âVon wem kÃ¶nnen wir uns eine Scheibe abschneiden?â, meaning âWho can we cut a slice from for ourselves?â The picture behind that popular German expression is that everyone makes their own cake or loaf of bread and you can âtake a sliceâ from everyone you meet or, in other words, learn a thing or two from them and become a better version of yourself that way.

There are almost two-hundred countries in the world and the truth is that they all have their advantages and disadvantages. The trick is to bring home the best slices of each country you travel to. That way, we all get to learn from each other and pick and choose only the best habits and characteristics from cultures across the world.
